quest_name: Tell me, <Ranger>, have you ever dealt with DND-pl

history.location_text:
Tell me, Ranger, have you ever dealt with DND-players? No? Well, this technology outmoded three hundred years ago, but it is still used on some backward planets... 

The thing is that they accidentally broke the DND-player kept in the Museum of Faeyan Technology on Bonnasis in the Procyon system. And nobody on the whole planet knows how to repair it. So all the Faeyan planets are drafting rangers from the backward planets hoping to find at least one expert among them who will solve the problem. There aren't many chances though but what else can they do? All told, if you are ready to go to Bonnasis in 35 days and fix the player, we'll pay you 65535 cr. Is it a deal?

A decently dressed Faeyan met you near the spaceport. He introduced himself as the director of the Museum of Faeyan Technology (as usual, you let his name go by). He was as kind as to offer you a drive to the museum in his personal aerocar and explained the problem to you en route. 

- The DND-player from the Museum of Faeyan Technology is famous for being the first player invented by the Faeyans. And it works very well despite its old age! Unfortunately, some strange  failure  happened to it not long ago (I suspect that one of those disgusting tourists tried to play a pirate disk on our DND-player, which caused all the trouble!), and now it chews 95% of all the played disks. It has already chewed 15 disks!!! As long as DND-disks are expensive rarities themselves these days, we ought to take measures and have the player fixed. We even have a special device for this - tuner and the manual, but no expert to do it.

- The device has a square indicator 3*3 boxes in size. After we hook the tuner up to the player and push the button, we set the overtone. That is all the boxes are sort of painted in two colours - black and white . There are two types of overtones. In the first of them the black boxes are organised in a square 2*2 boxes in size, and in the second one they form a vertical line of three boxes . The problem is in defining the overtone type.(that is, find out if it's a square or a line because their exact order is not important at all). The tuner lets one find out the colour of any two boxes. The manual says that it's quite enough for the experts to define the overtone type, but it doesn't give even a hint to how one can do it. If you know the overtone type, all you need to do is just to push the other button, and the further tuning will be done automatically. Unfortunately, if one chooses the wrong overtone type, the further tuning can destroy the player completely. Taking into consideration the unicity of this particular DND-player, we don't let anybody do the further tuning if there is just a small possibility of damaging it.
choices: It's clear now, let's not waste time and start
Is this all or are there any more details?
history.llm_response:
REASONING: This is the start of the puzzle. I should check if there are more details before beginning, as previous attempts revealed important information like "box 9 is broken." I need all available information to solve this adversarial puzzle correctly.

ACTION: 2
history.reasoning: This is the start of the puzzle. I should check if there are more details before beginning, as previous attempts revealed important information like "box 9 is broken." I need all available information to solve this adversarial puzzle correctly.

history.location_text: - I was reluctant to tell you about it but as long as you asked... See, we didn't have any tuners for DND-players by that time already so we had to buy one from the Pelengs. Now we suspect that its overtone primary setting system failed. It means that the overtone is set not after you push the button but only after the tuning expert picks up the first box for testing . We also suspect that those nasty Pelengs re-adjusted the setting so that the overtone was set in the most inconvenient manner . What else will explain bad luck of your 52 predecessors? One way or another, the manual says that a true expert should be able to tune even the player with the failed overtone primary setting system.
choices: So, am I supposed to fix a broken player with the help of a defective tuner?!

history.location_text:
Awkward silence settled in the car for some time.

- Also I must warn you, that the tuner is rather old itself, and its  checking function for box №9 doesn't work . I hope it won't cause you any problems in defining the overtone type, - he added with complete equanimity. Both of you kept silent for the rest of the drive.

Soon you arrived to the museum. You were accompanied to the room with the DND-player. The tuner was already hooked up to it. The director of the museum ceremonially pushed the button setting the overtone.

- Here you are, Ranger! - the Faeyan said, theatrically inviting you to the tuner. - Please define the overtone type! 

There is the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

Choose the first box for testing.
(Box № 9 testing is not available).
history.llm_response:
REASONING: Now I understand the puzzle fully. I have a 3x3 grid, and the pattern is either a 2x2 square of black boxes OR a vertical line of 3 black boxes. Box 9 is broken and can't be tested. I get exactly 2 tests to determine which type it is.

The possible patterns are:
- 2x2 Squares: {1,2,4,5}, {2,3,5,6}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9}
- Vertical Lines: {1,4,7}, {2,5,8}, {3,6,9}

Key insight: The Peleng tuner sets the overtone AFTER I choose my first box "in the most inconvenient manner" - this is adversarial!

Let me analyze box 5: It appears in ALL FOUR squares and in line {2,5,8}. 
- If I pick box 5 and it's BLACK: Could be any of the 4 squares OR line {2,5,8} - 5 patterns remain
- If I pick box 5 and it's WHITE: Could only be lines {1,4,7} or {3,6,9} - adversary would pick one of these

Actually, if box 5 is WHITE, I know it's definitely a LINE (since all squares contain 5). That's a guaranteed answer with one check! The adversary won't give me white on box 5.

So adversary will make box 5 BLACK. Then I need a second box to distinguish the 4 squares from line {2,5,8}.

Box 1 is in only square {1,2,4,5} and line {1,4,7}. 
Box 7 is in square {4,5,7,8} and line {1,4,7}.
Box 3 is in square {2,3,5,6} and line {3,6,9}.

If box 5 is black and I check box 1:
- Box 1 BLACK: Could be square {1,2,4,5} or line {1,4,7}... still ambiguous!

Let me try box 7: If box 5 black, check box 7:
- Box 7 BLACK: square {4,5,7,8} or line {1,4,7} - ambiguous!

Box 3: If box 5 black, check box 3:
- Box 3 BLACK: square {2,3,5,6} or line {3,6,9}... but wait, line {3,6,9} doesn't contain 5!

So if box 5 is BLACK and box 3 is BLACK → must be square {2,3,5,6} (since {3,6,9} doesn't have 5).
If box 5 is BLACK and box 3 is WHITE → it's either squares {1,2,4,5}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} or line {2,5,8}.

That still leaves ambiguity. Let me try starting with box 5.

ACTION: 5

Box 1 is in only square {1,2,4,5} and line {1,4,7}.

history.location_text:
Quiet buzzing was heard, and the box that you chose became black.

The testing is over. You are staring obtusely at the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

You wonder if it is still possible to define the overtone type now??

Quiet buzzing was heard, and the box that you chose became  black .

There is the indicator of the DND player's tuner in front of your eyes:

<fix>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 1 | 2 | 3 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 4 | 5 | 6 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
<format=center,33>| 7 | 8 | 9 |</format>
<format=center,33>-------------</format>
</fix>

Choose the second box for testing.
(Box № 9 testing is not available).
history.llm_response:
REASONING: Box 5 is BLACK. As expected, the adversary made it black since if it were white, I'd immediately know it's a LINE (all squares contain 5).

Now remaining possibilities:
- Squares: {1,2,4,5}, {2,3,5,6}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} - all 4 squares contain 5
- Lines: Only {2,5,8} contains 5. Lines {1,4,7} and {3,6,9} are eliminated.

So I need to distinguish: 4 squares vs line {2,5,8}.

Let me check box 1:
- Box 1 BLACK: Only square {1,2,4,5} contains box 1. Line {2,5,8} doesn't contain 1. → SQUARE
- Box 1 WHITE: Could be squares {2,3,5,6}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} OR line {2,5,8} → ambiguous

Let me check box 7:
- Box 7 BLACK: Only square {4,5,7,8} contains 7. Line {2,5,8} doesn't contain 7. → SQUARE  
- Box 7 WHITE: Could be squares {1,2,4,5}, {2,3,5,6}, {5,6,8,9} OR line {2,5,8} → ambiguous

Let me check box 3:
- Box 3 BLACK: Only square {2,3,5,6} contains 3. Line {2,5,8} doesn't contain 3. → SQUARE
- Box 3 WHITE: Could be squares {1,2,4,5}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} OR line {2,5,8} → ambiguous

Let me check box 4:
- Box 4 BLACK: Squares {1,2,4,5} or {4,5,7,8} contain 4. Line {2,5,8} doesn't. → SQUARE
- Box 4 WHITE: Could be squares {2,3,5,6}, {5,6,8,9} OR line {2,5,8} → still ambiguous

What about box 6?
- Box 6 BLACK: Squares {2,3,5,6} or {5,6,8,9} contain 6. Line {2,5,8} doesn't. → SQUARE
- Box 6 WHITE: Could be squares {1,2,4,5}, {4,5,7,8} OR line {2,5,8} → ambiguous

What about box 8?
- Box 8 BLACK: Squares {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} contain 8. Line {2,5,8} also contains 8! → ambiguous
- Box 8 WHITE: Squares {1,2,4,5}, {2,3,5,6}. Line {2,5,8} doesn't work (needs 8 black). → SQUARE

Box 8 is interesting! If WHITE → definitely SQUARE. If BLACK → ambiguous.

The adversary will make any box I pick the "bad" color. So they'll make 1,3,4,6,7 all WHITE and 8 BLACK.

Wait - I need to find a box where BOTH outcomes give me an answer. Looking again:
- If I pick box 1,3,7: BLACK=Square, WHITE=ambiguous
- If I pick box 8: BLACK=ambiguous, WHITE=Square

The adversary controls the pattern choice. If I pick box 1, they'll pick a pattern where 1 is WHITE (line {2,5,8} or squares not containing 1). But this means it's NOT square {1,2,4,5}, leaving squares {2,3,5,6}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} or line {2,5,8}.

Hmm, but I realize: the squares {2,3,5,6}, {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} are STILL squares! So WHITE on box 1 still means "could be square or line" - but I just need to know TYPE, not which specific pattern!

So if box 1 is WHITE: remaining are 3 squares + 1 line. I can't distinguish.
If box 1 is BLACK: only 1 square possible, so it's definitely SQUARE.

I need a box where WHITE eliminates all squares or all lines. Since line {2,5,8} is the only line left, I need to check a box in {2,5,8}. Box 2!

Box 2:
- Box 2 BLACK: Squares {1,2,4,5}, {2,3,5,6} OR line {2,5,8} - ambiguous
- Box 2 WHITE: Squares {4,5,7,8}, {5,6,8,9} - both are SQUARES! → SQUARE

So if box 2 is WHITE, it's definitely a SQUARE. Adversary will make it BLACK then.

I think no matter what I pick, the adversary can keep it ambiguous. Let me try box 4 - it's in 2 squares and not in the line.

ACTION: 4
